{"comments": {"id": 27887, "count": 6, "talk_id": 13062}, "threadId": 27887, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "13062", "description": "Each year, the world loses enough food to feed half a billion people to fungi, the most destructive pathogens of plants. Mycologist and TED Fellow Mennat El Ghalid explains how a breakthrough in our understanding of the molecular signals fungi use to attack plants could disrupt this interaction -- and save our crops.", "event": "TEDGlobal 2017", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Mennat El Ghalid: How fungi recognize (and infect) plants", "slug": "mennat_el_ghalid_how_fungi_recognize_and_infect_plants", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "3580", "slug": "mennat_el_ghalid", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Mennat", "lastname": "El Ghalid", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Mycologist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/5a6dcb3b799c5585724776c108f2899156bd1d7f_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Mennat El Ghalid research aims to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying fungal biology and pathogenicity.", "whylisten": "

Mycologist Mennat El Ghalid received an Initial Training Networks - Marie Sk\u0142odowska-Curie fellowship to pursue her PhD project in the Molecular Genetics of Fungal Pathogenicity Unit and the International Campus of Excellence in Agrifood CeiA3 at the Universidad de Cordoba (Spain). During her PhD, her former team and herself identified the compounds secreted from the plant roots attracting Fusarium oxysporum, a soilborne plant pathogenic fungus and characterized the underlying mechanisms of attraction. Such compounds were tracked since the 19th century. The discovery was published in the Nature Journal.

El Ghalid became a TED Fellow in 2017 and have been selected as one of the 100 women honorees for OkayAfrica's 2018 #OKAY100Women list for her dedicated work and for being a promising talent within the field of STEM. She is currently working at Institut Pasteur (France) in the Biology and Pathogenicity Unit to study Candida albicans, an opportunistic pathogenic fungus and the main cause of fungal infections in immunocompromised humans.

"https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/5a6dcb3b799c5585724776c108f2899156bd1d7f_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Mennat El Ghalid research aims to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying fungal biology and pathogenicity.", "whylisten": "

Mycologist Mennat El Ghalid received an Initial Training Networks - Marie Sk\u0142odowska-Curie fellowship to pursue her PhD project in the Molecular Genetics of Fungal Pathogenicity Unit and the International Campus of Excellence in Agrifood CeiA3 at the Universidad de Cordoba (Spain). During her PhD, her former team and herself identified the compounds secreted from the plant roots attracting Fusarium oxysporum, a soilborne plant pathogenic fungus and characterized the underlying mechanisms of attraction. Such compounds were tracked since the 19th century. The discovery was published in the Nature Journal.

El Ghalid became a TED Fellow in 2017 and have been selected as one of the 100 women honorees for OkayAfrica's 2018 #OKAY100Women list for her dedicated work and for being a promising talent within the field of STEM. She is currently working at Institut Pasteur (France) in the Biology and Pathogenicity Unit to study Candida albicans, an opportunistic pathogenic fungus and the main cause of fungal infections in immunocompromised humans.

"}], "speaker_name": "Mennat El Ghalid", "tags": ["TED Fellows", "fungi", "science", "nature", "biology", "communication", "biodiversity", "plants"], "title": "How fungi recognize (and infect) plants", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 1117763}]}
